review_blob: 550ml bottle.  Pours clear copper in color with a thin tan head.  Smells of caramel and something tart I cant quite place.  The taste is malty with notes of caramel and bread, with mild hop bitterness.  This is a relatively light beer and feels slightly under-carbonated.  This is a balanced beer and very sessionable.
beer_name: Samuel Smiths Organic / Old Brewery Pale Ale

review_blob: 12oz bottle.  Pours hazy amber with thin head.  Smells slightly malty and hoppy - caramel and grassy notes.  Thin bodied, with a strong sweet flavor up front and a bitter bite at the end with an odd, soapy aftertaste.  Ive had this before and it was better, but this is borderline drainpour.  The flavors do not blend at all, and light carbonation leaves off flavors to linger on the tongue.

22oz bottle, served at cellar temp in a tulip.  Pours clear copper-brown with a little bit of tan head, faint lacing.  Smells strong - caramel, toffee, resinous hop and pine with a detectable odor of alcohol.  Taste is sweet and malty, with notes of caramel, almost-but-not-quite-balanced by burst of grassy, pine hop bitterness at the end.  Full-bodied mouthfeel.  If only the hops were better balanced - another year in the cellar might help with the balance.  However, if it were hopped a little more, it might make for a good IIPA.
beer_name: Widmer Brothers Reserve Galaxy Hopped Barleywine

review_blob: 750ml corked bottle from 05/2011, served in a globe.  Pours a thick brown with a finger of tan head with good staying power.  Smells rich and malty - toffee, molasses,  currants, figs.  Medium full body, with rich bourbon and vanilla flavor, trailing notes of chocolate toffee, and caramel.  Its delicious, but would benefit for a year or two in the cellar to let the flavors blend and mellow a bit.

22oz, served in a globe.  Pours very clear amber, thin white head, slight lacing.  Smells grassy, pine, slightly citrus.  Medium full body, strong and balanced malt/hop flavors - caramel, pine, citrus rind, with a piney bitter aftertaste that lingers.  The malt/hop balance is just about perfect and balances well with the alcohol content.

Growler from draft, served in a globe.  Pours dark, hazy amber/copper, lightly carbonated with almost no head.  The aroma is fruity, mango and pineapple, with tart undertones.  Medium-full body, again lightly carbonated.  The flavor is malty with strong tropical fruit flavors and a hint of citrus.  There is no real bitterness, and at 11+% ABV, there is very little alcohol warmth.  This is a delicious, but dangerous beer.  I do think it could use a bit more carbonation to help balance the strong fruitiness.

750ml bottle.  Pours hazy amber, rocky white head with staying power and nice lacing.  Smells of belgian funk - grassy barnyard.  Medium body, with a malty, semi-sweet start and a sour, spicy finish.  Upright four is outstanding on its own, but the barrel aging and addition of the peppers takes it over the top.  The peppers build over time, with a nice, slowly increasing burn, without becoming dominating.

22oz bottle, 2011 Reserve.  Pours hazy orange copper, light white head.  No head retention or lacing.  Strong hoppy aroma, with notes of citrus and pine, with a caramel/toffee background.  Medium body, not over carbonated, slick mouthfeel.  Flavor is big and hoppy - citrus flavors up front and pine on the backend, with a good malty hit in between.

22oz bottle.  Pours a dark, slightly hazy copper color with a meager head.  Funky nose, smells tangy and faintly of caramel and molasses.  Thin body for a bigger beer.  Apricot flavors, caramel, toffee, and a tang that I can almost describe as salty.  Interesting and complex, but much better on draft at the brewery.

750ml corked bottle, 2011 vintage.  Served in a globe. Pours a deep ruby brown with about a finger of large-bubbled tan head that dissipates quickly.  Light lacing on the glass.  Smells fruity, oak and vanilla.  Medium body with a very smooth mouthfeel.  Tastes of vanilla and dark sugar/molasses sweetness, with hints of oak and sour cherries left behind.  The cherry really stands out as the beer warms.

11.2 oz. bottle.  Pours very dark brown, thin oily white head.  Smells malty sweet - toffee and caramel.  Medium body, somewhat oily mouthfeel.  Tastes sweet upfront with brown sugar, caramel, and toffee and then fades with grains, barely detectable bitterness, and alcohol warmth.  This is an indulgent doppelbock, both in flavor and price ($5.99/bottle).  Worth the money if youre a fan of the style, but there are other excellent doppelbocks that can be had for half the price.

Served on draft.  Nice and dark, tan head, moderate lacing.  Smells deeply of coffee, roasted malt, and pine.  Medium body, nice carbonation.  The flavor is typical of a black IPA or CDA, with added notes of coffee.  I find this intriguing and delicious - coffee and beer are two of my favorite things.  The coffee flavor does not overpower, and balances nicely with the roasted malt and hops.

Draft.  Light golden color with a thin white head, no lacing.  Smells like a pilsner - grassy, cereal grains, with an added hint of nuttiness.  Light bodied, good carbonation.  Well-balance pilsner taste - barley and slightly spice hops, with a sweet, nutty twist from the filberts (hazelnuts).

On draft at Ventis for Gilgamesh pairing dinner.  Dark brown with ruby tones (dim lighting), thin head with minimal lacing.  Smells intensely of chocolate.  The taste is very dry, chocolate and roasted malt with coffee undertones, a hint of cherry sweetness and a very mild bitterness.  Medium bodied with light carbonation.  It paired very well with the dinner entree (beef short ribs) and has a well-balance profile.

12oz bottle.  Pours black, faint ruby light peeks through my pint glass.  One finger of tan head, slight lacing.  Resinous, hoppy aroma - pine and citrus, with maybe a faint hint of roasted malt, but that may just be in my head.  Thin mouthfeel, strong citrusy hop flavor.  Faint roasted malty notes, but the hops really overpower.  This tastes like a plain IPA that happens to be black - Id really like to taste a little more of the "black" flavors to balance the bitterness and really represent the style.

Growler from draft.  Pours thick and black, with a tan head, slight lacing on the glass.  Smells roasted with chocolate notes.  Lighter body, strong roasted malt flavor, chocolate, sweet notes and just a lingering hint of coffee.

22oz bottle.  Served in a globe.  Pours a deep, hazy copper with a thin head that dissipates quickly.  Strong floral aroma of hop goodness with malty undertones - caramel and toffee - and a hint of earthy oak.  Medium bodied, thick and carbonated, with a heavy, but balanced assault of malts and hops - caramel sweetness with vanilla from the oak and subtle notes of citrus and pine.  A fine improvement on an already fine brew.

22oz bottle.  Served in a globe. Pours clear copper, one finger of white head with good lacing on the glass.  Smells of hops - pine, resin, citrus, grass.  Medium body, nicely balanced between malt sweetness and hops.  Caramel flavors, citrus, and a wonderful lingering bitterness and not a hint of alcohol.  One of my favorite DIPAs.

750ml bottle.  Served in a globe.  Pours hazy amber, thick, almost rocky white head that stays and good lacing on the glass.  Smells of belgian funk, grass, hoppy florals.  Medium bodied mouthfeel and silky smooth carbonation.  Stats with sweet flavors up front with hop floral and bitterness at the end.  Musty yeast and spicy notes to complement the sweetness, nice warmth from the ABV.

12oz. bottle.  Pours a clear copper red, off-white head, good lacing.  Floral hop aroma - pine, grass, little bit of citrus.  Medium body with a hop-heavy flavor, slight malt sweetness, but primarily pine and citrus with a faint sweetness at the finish.  Though I prefer big brother Brrrbon, this is a nice seasonal winter IPA.

22oz bottle, 2011 (it goes to 11).  Served in a globe.  Dark, hazy amber in color with about an inch of head that fades to a ring, slight lacing on the glass.  Tropical fruity aroma, some hop notes.  Medium-thin body, with a malty hoppy flavor and definite alcohol warmth, faint traces of caramel and citrus rind.  Except for the strength, this tastes a lot more like an under-hopped imperial IPA than a barleywine. Not a bad beer to drink at all, but as a barleywine its just too thin on the palate and needs balance with "darker" flavors - figs, raisins, toffee - to measure up.

22oz bottle.  Pours hazy golden, very carbonated, with a thick, rocky white head and good lacing, as I would expect from a Belgian ale.  The aroma is rather bland, though, with a generic ester alcohol odor that lacks any real character.  Medium body, high carbonation.  Flavor is sweet and estery, but like the aroma lacks any real character.  As it warms up, a distinct skunky flavor begins to assert itself - almost undrinkable.
beer_name: Left Coast Asylum Belgian-Style Tripel Ale

review_blob: 22oz. bottle, 2010.  Pours a nice hazy reddish brown, one finger of tan head, minimal lacing.  Complex aroma, a little alcohol, malty sweet, molasses, figs, dates, and a little toffee.  Medium-to-thin mouthfeel.  Rich flavor - molasses, brown sugar, raisins, spices, lingering caramel and toffee with mild bitterness.  Very well-balanced and smooth for a big beer.

22oz bottle.  Pours a dark amber, very little head, but nice lacing.  Floral hop aroma, slight pine notes.  Medium body, creamy mouthfeel.  Malty, bitter flavor, bready, slighty woody.  Nice bitter hop afterglow.  Very good, balanced ESB.

Growler from draft at Ventis.  Deep ruby-brown, light tan head, good lacing.  Smells spicy - clove, cinnamon, spruce.  Medium bodied, slick mouthfeel.  Heavy malt and spice flavor - spruce, cinnamon, nutmeg, maybe allspice.  Im not a big fan of spiced beers, but this combo tickles my taste buds just right, which is good since I have 3 more pints worth to finish before it goes flat...

750ml bottle.  Pours a deep, dark brown with a thick tan head that holds on well, but doesnt lace at all.  Rich, malty sweet aroma, hints of clove and cinnamon.  Full mouth feel, strong malt flavor with notes of brown sugar and caramel and a slight alcohol burn. A passable, if plain rendition of the style.

22oz bottle.  Pours motor oil black, like any respectable imperial stout, with a finger of tan head that sticks around.  All I can smell are roasty malt, slight coffee and chocolate notes.  Nice malty, roasty, flavor up front, with notes of chocolate and coffee, chocolaty bittersweet finish.  Full bodied mouthfeel.  Very delicious.

On draft at Ventis. Dark amber/red color with a white head that laces nicely.  Sugary, slightly spicy aroma.  Medium bodied with a rich, spicy malt flavor, hints of clove and cinnamon. Dark is misleading here - its not a dark beer and doesnt have any toasty flavors, which wouldnt really go with the style.

2010 vintage on draft served in a tulip.  Deep red color, light head. Good lacing. Malty sweet alcohol aroma with a hint of florals. Smooth, full body. Assertive malt flavor with alcohol and a nice trailing hop finish. Flavors intensify as the beer warms. Wonderful barley wine

22oz. bottle.  Pours almost midnight black, tan head that hangs around.  Has a nice "dry" roasty aroma, slightly sweet smell.  Roasty flavor, slightly dry.  Hints of chocolate and coffee.  Medium bodied.  Mildly bitter at first, but the bitter afterglow gets harsh as it lingers.  A passable porter, but probably not something I would pick up again.

22oz bottle.  Clear amber color, white head that laces nicely.  Smells faintly hoppy floral and grassy.  Taste is a sweet, hoppy floral malt punch with a long, mellow bitter afterbite.  Its a lot of hop, but its still pretty well balanced by the malt bill.

1L bottle from Gilgamesh.  Pours jet black like any respectable stout.  Thin tan head that retreats to a ring, minimal lacing, not very carbonated.  Smells like minty chocolate.  Tastes much the same - chocolate roasty minty.  No bitterness - even my wife likes this one.  Thin body for a stout, but still a great dessert beer to share with friends.

On draft, 2011 served in a tulip. Pitch black with a thick brown head, nice lacing on the glass. Rich molasses vanilla oak aroma. Chewy mouthfeel, stron favors of molasses, toffee, vanilla, bourbon and oak. Lingering alcohol and toffee favors. This is a massive, delicious beer to sip on.
beer_name: Full Sail Black Gold Imperial Stout Bourbon Barrel Aged

review_blob: 22 oz bottle, 2011.  Thick, dark, hazy copper color.  Thin tan head that disappears to a white ring, light lacing down the glass.  Big malty smells - molasses and caramel, muted hop notes.  Full bodied mouthfeel, big malty flavors - again with the molasses, caramel, toffee, oak - and a good dose of piney hop flavor, lingering bitterness for a well-balanced profile.

22 oz bottle, 2011.  Pours dark amber, almost brown, very little head that retreats to a white ring, no lacing to speak of. Smells sweet, malty, caramel, mild alcohol.  Tastes malty, caramel, gingerbread?, mild bitterness at the finish.  Full bodied mouthfeel.  Not bad for an american interpretation of the dubbel style.
beer_name: Full Sail Sanctuary Belgian Style Dubbel

review_blob: 22oz bomber.  Deep copper, off white head that tries to hang around.  Malty, heavy floral hop aroma with lots of pine, hints of citrus.  Heavy combo of malt and pine flavor up front with hints of citrus rind, and a pleasant linqering bitterness.  Medium body, clean mouthfeel.  This is a beefy imperial IPA well suited for a chilly winter night.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a deep brown color, 1/2" of pale brown head.  Roasty and nutty, malty sweet with a nutty finish and lingering hop bitterness.  Medium body. Smells of roast malt and nuts.  Very complex and flavorful for a brown ale.

Growler from tap at Ventis.  Pours a clean amber, half inch of white head that dissipated quickly, not much lacing.  Malty sweet aroma with floral hop notes.  Medium body, malty sweet flavor, lots of hop flavor with only a mildly bitter finish.
beer_name: Fish Tale Organic Winterfish Seasonal Ale

review_blob: On tap at Ventis served in a tulip. Dark (duh) with a lot of thick tan head that sticks to the sides of the glass. A lot of head. Smells roasty and chocolate, but not a lot of aroma. Taste is roasty, chocolate, coffee, slight licorice. Medium body for an imperial stout. The alcohol isnt prominent. Flavors intensify as It warms up. Wish th had barrel aged to sample...
beer_name: Laughing Dog The Dogfather Imperial Stout

review_blob: On draft at Ventis.  Light copper color, white head with decent lacing. Smells citrusy and spicy. Big hop flavor up front with a pleasant lingering bitterness at the end. Medium body. Typical of the NW IPA style, though still light in color enough to qualify as pale.

22oz bomber. Pours a hazy orange with a thin white head.  Aroma of banana, clove, slight alcohol.  Medium-full bodied on the tongue, with initial crash of banana/clove flavors and finishing with a mild alcohol bite and lingering spicy flavors.

22oz, Dec 2009 vintage with Don Younger on the label.  Pours thick dark brown, 1/2" of tan head that dissipates quickly.  Smells of vanilla, molasses,   slight caramel and figs or dates.  Full bodied on the palate, malty vanilla bourbon oak assault with a lingering caramel/vanilla/toffee aftertaste. Theres a slight hint of alcohol, but not much for a big beer.

22oz. bomber, Brrrbon 11.  Pours a dark amber in color, very little head. Smells a little spicy, alcohol, oak, caramel, figs.  Thin bodied with a malty flavor, slight oak notes, fig/date flavors. If I didnt know this was aged in bourbon barrels, I wouldnt be able to pick out the very faint hints of booze.  As it warms up the flavors become a little more pronounced.  The high ABV is well hidden, but overall this years batch isnt nearly as balanced as the 10 - disappointing, but still a good beer overall
beer_name: Widmer Brothers Reserve Barrel Aged Brrrbon

review_blob: 750ml bottle - its a gusher, open it over the sink.  Slightly cloudy, light amber in color with a thick, rocky head and nice lacing.  Smells a little funky, grassy, lemony.  Full bodied mouthfeel, slightly fruity saison flavor with just a hint of brett funk.  A good beer, though I think I prefer the regular Seizoen.

22oz. bottle.  Pours very dark, thick amber head.  Smells of vanilla, clove, figs.  Medium body.  Sweet, roasty, vanilla, oak, bourbon, alcohol warmth.  Lingering spiced afterglow.  Its expensive, but the incredible flavor profile and rich aromas are worth the expense.  One of the best beers I have enjoyed in quite some time.

From 750ml corked bottle.  Poured a nice golden color, thick head, nice lacing.  Smelled like a typical strong belgian golden (phenol) and slight citrus notes.  Very carbonated, light on the tongue.  Lots of warmth from the alcohol, slight citrusy hop notes on the way down and in the aftertaste.

22 oz bottle. Pours a dark amber, thin head that dissipated quickly.  No real lacing, though Ill note that Ive had this on draft and it had a much better head/lacing.  Spicy aroma - the chiles come through nicely.  First sip tastes like a belgian amber, hint of cinnamon, light bitterness and little hop aftertaste. As it warms up, the chiles come through, adding a somewhat salty, "olive brine" flavor.  I missed out on the early vertical releases, but this is by far my favorite thus far.  Very unusual.

Growler fill from draft courtesy Ventis.  Pours a clean, golden amber with an almost-white head.  Bold hop aroma with strong citrus notes.  Good body, caramel malt, strong hop bitterness going down with a delightful grapefruit rind aftertaste that fades nicely.  This is a well-balanced, strong IPA.

Picked this up at Trader Joes in Salem.  Unique swing-top bottle, opens with a good pop.  Pours a clean reddish amber in color with a couple fingers of pale head.  Moderate lacing.  Has a slight hop aroma, but not enough to really pick anything out. Bottle says its an ale, but it tastes more like a malty mrzen lager.  Thin mouthfeel.  Far from the worst $3.49 Ive spent on a pint, but probably not something I would buy again.
